instruction: How can you use a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable or an array?
output: To use a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable or an array, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person variable in the 'Film' reference variable, use the following statement: film.person = 'Smith'. Similarly, to set the title attribute to the value of 'ANNIE HALL', use the statement movies[i].title = 'ANNIE HALL'.

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second, 
movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

For information about referencing the individual elements in a reference or array variable, see Reference Variables 
and Dynamic Array Variables.

instruction: Can simple variables be nullable in OpenROAD?
output: Yes, by default all simple variables are nullable in OpenROAD. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 'not null' clause in the variable declaration, for example: i = integer not null;

# Reference Variables

A reference variable is a variable that points to an object of a given class, letting you access the value of an 
object. An object is a compound data structure that holds values that you can manipulate. A reference variable does 
not store its own values. Instead, when you reference the reference variable, OpenROAD uses the values in the 
corresponding object. The object is made up of attributes, which can be simple variables, reference variables, or 
array variables.

The class of an object defines its attributes. OpenROAD includes both system classes and user-defined classes.

In your 4GL code, when you reference a reference variable, you can work with the entire object as a single unit. For 
example, you can retrieve a row from a database table and assign all values from the row to a single object and then 
pass the object to a called procedure. You can also work with the individual attributes in the object.

## How You Can Declare Reference Variables

To declare a reference variable, use the following syntax:

```
name = class [ [with] default null]
```

The value of class can be any named user class or system class (for a complete list of system classes, see the 
Language Reference Guide online help). The following example declares a reference variable of the StringObject class:

```
strobj = StringObject;
```

All reference variables are nullable.

When you create a field on a form, you specify the variable's name and data type on the field's property inspector in 
the OpenROAD Workbench. Unless you specify otherwise, OpenROAD automatically declares the variable that you use to 
access the data in that field. If the field is a named composite field, such as a stackfield or subform, the variable 
is a reference variable and you may or may not define its data type (class).

If you do define the data type for the reference variable, the data type must be a system or user class name. You can 
choose to exclude fields for some of the attributes (this provides a way to keep additional undisplayed control 
information).

If you do not name the class when you create a composite field, OpenROAD creates an unnamed class that you can 
reference only within the frame that contains the composite field.

## How You Can Use Reference Variables

In OpenROAD, you can work with an object as a whole or with the attributes of the object. To manipulate the object as 
a single unit, use the name of the object's reference variable in your 4GL code.

For example, you can create a subform and specify its variable's class as a named user class. In your program you 
could then pass the values in the subform fields to a procedure simply by naming the variable as a procedure 
parameter.

In the following statement, customer is the name of the variable associated with a subform:

```
callproc update_cust (new = customer)
```

To access an individual attribute that belongs to an object, use the dot notation:

```
referencevariable_name.attribute_name
```

For example, assume that the subform previously described contained a field called Address. To reference that field, 
you would use:

```
customer.Address
```

In the following example, City and Street are attributes of class addr, and address is a declared reference variable:

```
address.City = 'Dallas';
x = address.Street;
callframe delete_old (address = address.City);
```

OpenROAD checks references to attributes by name and produces compiler errors if the variable's class does not 
contain those attributes. For example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
tmp_char = varchar(30) not null;
```

Some valid references would be:

```
a.Street = tmp_char;
tmp_char = a.city;
```

Some invalid references would be:

```
a.Province = tmp_char;  /*  ERROR at compile time
                        ** because attribute 'province'
                        ** is not defined for class 'addr' */
a = null;
a.Street = tmp_char;    /*  ERROR at runtime because 'a' is
                        ** null, and does not reference
                        ** an object */
```

## Null Reference Variables

When you declare a reference variable without specifying default null, the variable points to an object whose 
attributes are automatically initialized with the default values given in the definition of the object. However, you 
can set a reference variable to null. A reference variable that is set to null does not point to any object. Whenever 
all reference variables for an object have been redirected or set to null, OpenROAD frees the associated object, for 
example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
```

The consequences of resetting the variables a and b would be:

```
a = b;     /*  The original object for a is freed. Now
            ** both a and b point to the same object. */
a = null;  /*  The object created for b still has 1
            ** reference (b). */
b = null:  /*  The object created for b is freed. */
```

As an alternative, you can specify default null on the declaration and a default object is not created.

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

```
if a is null then
    /* processing statements */
endif;
```

For more information about null reference variables, see Nulls in Expressions.

## How You Can Create Objects for Reference Variables

You may need to create an object for a reference variable. For example, dynamic programs can create fields or forms 
at runtime by using the Create method, defined for the Class class. The Create method returns an object of a 
specified class.

In the following example, the reference variable a is declared with a default value of null:

```
a = Addr default null;
```

And a new object is created for it:

```
a = Addr.Create();    /* Creates an Addr object */
a.Street = 'main street';
a.City = 'dallas';
```

For more information about the Create method, see the Class class Create Method. Examples of using the Create method 
are provided in "Creating a Frame at Runtime" in the Programming Guide.

corresponding object. The object is made up of attributes, which can be simple variables, reference variables, or

example, you can retrieve a row from a database table and assign all values from the row to a single object and then 
pass the object to a called procedure. You can also work with the individual attributes in the object.

To declare a reference variable, use the following syntax:

```
name = class [ [with] default null]
```

The value of class can be any named user class or system class (for a complete list of system classes, see the 
Language Reference Guide online help). The following example declares a reference variable of the StringObject class:

parameter.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

```

```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the

the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```

```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

variable, use the following statement:

person = 'Smith';

simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

# Reference Variables

object. An object is a compound data structure that holds values that you can manipulate. A reference variable does 
not store its own values. Instead, when you reference the reference variable, OpenROAD uses the values in the 
corresponding object. The object is made up of attributes, which can be simple variables, reference variables, or 
array variables.

The class of an object defines its attributes. OpenROAD includes both system classes and user-defined classes.

In your 4GL code, when you reference a reference variable, you can work with the entire object as a single unit. For 
example, you can retrieve a row from a database table and assign all values from the row to a single object and then 
pass the object to a called procedure. You can also work with the individual attributes in the object.

## How You Can Declare Reference Variables

To declare a reference variable, use the following syntax:

```
name = class [ [with] default null]
```

The value of class can be any named user class or system class (for a complete list of system classes, see the 
Language Reference Guide online help). The following example declares a reference variable of the StringObject class:

```
strobj = StringObject;
```

All reference variables are nullable.

When you create a field on a form, you specify the variable's name and data type on the field's property inspector in 
the OpenROAD Workbench. Unless you specify otherwise, OpenROAD automatically declares the variable that you use to 
access the data in that field. If the field is a named composite field, such as a stackfield or subform, the variable 
is a reference variable and you may or may not define its data type (class).

If you do define the data type for the reference variable, the data type must be a system or user class name. You can 
choose to exclude fields for some of the attributes (this provides a way to keep additional undisplayed control 
information).

If you do not name the class when you create a composite field, OpenROAD creates an unnamed class that you can 
reference only within the frame that contains the composite field.

## How You Can Use Reference Variables

In OpenROAD, you can work with an object as a whole or with the attributes of the object. To manipulate the object as 
a single unit, use the name of the object's reference variable in your 4GL code.

For example, you can create a subform and specify its variable's class as a named user class. In your program you 
could then pass the values in the subform fields to a procedure simply by naming the variable as a procedure 
parameter.

In the following statement, customer is the name of the variable associated with a subform:

```
callproc update_cust (new = customer)
```

To access an individual attribute that belongs to an object, use the dot notation:

```
referencevariable_name.attribute_name
```

For example, assume that the subform previously described contained a field called Address. To reference that field, 
you would use:

```
customer.Address
```

In the following example, City and Street are attributes of class addr, and address is a declared reference variable:

```
address.City = 'Dallas';
x = address.Street;
callframe delete_old (address = address.City);
```

OpenROAD checks references to attributes by name and produces compiler errors if the variable's class does not 
contain those attributes. For example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
tmp_char = varchar(30) not null;
```

Some valid references would be:

```
a.Street = tmp_char;
tmp_char = a.city;
```

Some invalid references would be:

```
a.Province = tmp_char;  /*  ERROR at compile time
                        ** because attribute 'province'
                        ** is not defined for class 'addr' */
a = null;
a.Street = tmp_char;    /*  ERROR at runtime because 'a' is
                        ** null, and does not reference
                        ** an object */
```

## Null Reference Variables

When you declare a reference variable without specifying default null, the variable points to an object whose 
attributes are automatically initialized with the default values given in the definition of the object. However, you 
can set a reference variable to null. A reference variable that is set to null does not point to any object. Whenever 
all reference variables for an object have been redirected or set to null, OpenROAD frees the associated object, for 
example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
```

The consequences of resetting the variables a and b would be:

```
a = b;     /*  The original object for a is freed. Now
            ** both a and b point to the same object. */
a = null;  /*  The object created for b still has 1
            ** reference (b). */
b = null:  /*  The object created for b is freed. */
```

As an alternative, you can specify default null on the declaration and a default object is not created.

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

```
if a is null then
    /* processing statements */
endif;
```

For more information about null reference variables, see Nulls in Expressions.

## How You Can Create Objects for Reference Variables

You may need to create an object for a reference variable. For example, dynamic programs can create fields or forms 
at runtime by using the Create method, defined for the Class class. The Create method returns an object of a 
specified class.

In the following example, the reference variable a is declared with a default value of null:

```
a = Addr default null;
```

And a new object is created for it:

```
a = Addr.Create();    /* Creates an Addr object */
a.Street = 'main street';
a.City = 'dallas';
```

For more information about the Create method, see the Class class Create Method. Examples of using the Create method 
are provided in "Creating a Frame at Runtime" in the Programming Guide.

document:
# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second,

not store its own values. Instead, when you reference the reference variable, OpenROAD uses the values in the 
corresponding object. The object is made up of attributes, which can be simple variables, reference variables, or 
array variables.

The class of an object defines its attributes. OpenROAD includes both system classes and user-defined classes.

In your 4GL code, when you reference a reference variable, you can work with the entire object as a single unit. For 
example, you can retrieve a row from a database table and assign all values from the row to a single object and then 
pass the object to a called procedure. You can also work with the individual attributes in the object.

## How You Can Declare Reference Variables

To declare a reference variable, use the following syntax:

```
name = class [ [with] default null]
```

The value of class can be any named user class or system class (for a complete list of system classes, see the 
Language Reference Guide online help). The following example declares a reference variable of the StringObject class:

```
strobj = StringObject;
```

All reference variables are nullable.

When you create a field on a form, you specify the variable's name and data type on the field's property inspector in 
the OpenROAD Workbench. Unless you specify otherwise, OpenROAD automatically declares the variable that you use to 
access the data in that field. If the field is a named composite field, such as a stackfield or subform, the variable 
is a reference variable and you may or may not define its data type (class).

If you do define the data type for the reference variable, the data type must be a system or user class name. You can 
choose to exclude fields for some of the attributes (this provides a way to keep additional undisplayed control 
information).

If you do not name the class when you create a composite field, OpenROAD creates an unnamed class that you can 
reference only within the frame that contains the composite field.

## How You Can Use Reference Variables

In OpenROAD, you can work with an object as a whole or with the attributes of the object. To manipulate the object as 
a single unit, use the name of the object's reference variable in your 4GL code.

For example, you can create a subform and specify its variable's class as a named user class. In your program you 
could then pass the values in the subform fields to a procedure simply by naming the variable as a procedure 
parameter.

In the following statement, customer is the name of the variable associated with a subform:

```
callproc update_cust (new = customer)
```

To access an individual attribute that belongs to an object, use the dot notation:

```
referencevariable_name.attribute_name
```

For example, assume that the subform previously described contained a field called Address. To reference that field, 
you would use:

```
customer.Address
```

In the following example, City and Street are attributes of class addr, and address is a declared reference variable:

```
address.City = 'Dallas';
x = address.Street;
callframe delete_old (address = address.City);
```

OpenROAD checks references to attributes by name and produces compiler errors if the variable's class does not 
contain those attributes. For example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
tmp_char = varchar(30) not null;
```

Some valid references would be:

```
a.Street = tmp_char;
tmp_char = a.city;
```

Some invalid references would be:

```
a.Province = tmp_char;  /*  ERROR at compile time
                        ** because attribute 'province'
                        ** is not defined for class 'addr' */
a = null;
a.Street = tmp_char;    /*  ERROR at runtime because 'a' is
                        ** null, and does not reference
                        ** an object */
```

When you declare a reference variable without specifying default null, the variable points to an object whose 
attributes are automatically initialized with the default values given in the definition of the object. However, you 
can set a reference variable to null. A reference variable that is set to null does not point to any object. Whenever 
all reference variables for an object have been redirected or set to null, OpenROAD frees the associated object, for 
example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
```

The consequences of resetting the variables a and b would be:

```
a = b;     /*  The original object for a is freed. Now
            ** both a and b point to the same object. */
a = null;  /*  The object created for b still has 1
            ** reference (b). */
b = null:  /*  The object created for b is freed. */
```

As an alternative, you can specify default null on the declaration and a default object is not created.

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

```
if a is null then
    /* processing statements */
endif;
```

For more information about null reference variables, see Nulls in Expressions.

## How You Can Create Objects for Reference Variables

You may need to create an object for a reference variable. For example, dynamic programs can create fields or forms 
at runtime by using the Create method, defined for the Class class. The Create method returns an object of a 
specified class.

```

```

```

a.Street = 'main street';
a.City = 'dallas';
```

are provided in "Creating a Frame at Runtime" in the Programming Guide.

if (a is null) then

```
processing statements
endif;
```

For more information about how to initialize or assign values to reference variables, see Reference Variables in Expressions.

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second, 
movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

For information about referencing the individual elements in a reference or array variable, see Reference Variables 
and Dynamic Array Variables.

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second, 
movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

For information about referencing the individual elements in a reference or array variable, see Reference Variables 
and Dynamic Array Variables.

instruction: What are some examples of how to use reference variables in OpenROAD programming language?
output:
Reference variables can be used in various ways in OpenROAD. For example, you can pass them as arguments to procedures, return them as values from procedures, or manipulate their attributes. Here are some examples:

* To assign the value of an attribute to a new variable, use the following syntax:

```
newvariable = referencevariable_name.attribute_name;
```

For example, assuming that the variable customer refers to a valid Addr object:

```
newcharvar = customer.Street;   /* Assigns the value of the 'street' attribute to newcharvar */
```

* To modify an attribute of a reference variable, use the following syntax:

```
referencevariable_name.attribute_name = newvalue;
```

For example, assuming that the variable customer refers to a valid Addr object, you can update its city attribute with this statement:

```
customer.City = 'Dallas';   /* Assigns the value 'Dallas' to the 'city' attribute */
```

* To check if a reference variable is null or not null, use the following syntax:

```
is null (referencevariable_name)
```

For example, you could check if the variable customer is null using this statement:

```
if is null(customer); then   /* Executes only if customer is null */
end if;
```

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';

simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

other simple variables, for example:

instruction: What are some best practices for working with reference variables in OpenROAD?
output:
Some best practices for working with reference variables include:

# Reference Variables

A reference variable is a variable that points to an object of a given class, letting you access the value of an 
object. An object is a compound data structure that holds values that you can manipulate. A reference variable does 
not store its own values. Instead, when you reference the reference variable, OpenROAD uses the values in the 
corresponding object. The object is made up of attributes, which can be simple variables, reference variables, or 
array variables.

The class of an object defines its attributes. OpenROAD includes both system classes and user-defined classes.

In your 4GL code, when you reference a reference variable, you can work with the entire object as a single unit. For 
example, you can retrieve a row from a database table and assign all values from the row to a single object and then 
pass the object to a called procedure. You can also work with the individual attributes in the object.

## How You Can Declare Reference Variables

To declare a reference variable, use the following syntax:

```
name = class [ [with] default null]
```

The value of class can be any named user class or system class (for a complete list of system classes, see the 
Language Reference Guide online help). The following example declares a reference variable of the StringObject class:

```
strobj = StringObject;
```

All reference variables are nullable.

When you create a field on a form, you specify the variable's name and data type on the field's property inspector in 
the OpenROAD Workbench. Unless you specify otherwise, OpenROAD automatically declares the variable that you use to 
access the data in that field. If the field is a named composite field, such as a stackfield or subform, the variable 
is a reference variable and you may or may not define its data type (class).

If you do define the data type for the reference variable, the data type must be a system or user class name. You can 
choose to exclude fields for some of the attributes (this provides a way to keep additional undisplayed control 
information).

If you do not name the class when you create a composite field, OpenROAD creates an unnamed class that you can 
reference only within the frame that contains the composite field.

## How You Can Use Reference Variables

In OpenROAD, you can work with an object as a whole or with the attributes of the object. To manipulate the object as 
a single unit, use the name of the object's reference variable in your 4GL code.

For example, you can create a subform and specify its variable's class as a named user class. In your program you 
could then pass the values in the subform fields to a procedure simply by naming the variable as a procedure 
parameter.

In the following statement, customer is the name of the variable associated with a subform:

```
callproc update_cust (new = customer)
```

To access an individual attribute that belongs to an object, use the dot notation:

```
referencevariable_name.attribute_name
```

For example, assume that the subform previously described contained a field called Address. To reference that field, 
you would use:

```
customer.Address
```

In the following example, City and Street are attributes of class addr, and address is a declared reference variable:

```
address.City = 'Dallas';
x = address.Street;
callframe delete_old (address = address.City);
```

OpenROAD checks references to attributes by name and produces compiler errors if the variable's class does not 
contain those attributes. For example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
tmp_char = varchar(30) not null;
```

Some valid references would be:

```
a.Street = tmp_char;
tmp_char = a.city;
```

Some invalid references would be:

```
a.Province = tmp_char;  /*  ERROR at compile time
                        ** because attribute 'province'
                        ** is not defined for class 'addr' */
a = null;
a.Street = tmp_char;    /*  ERROR at runtime because 'a' is
                        ** null, and does not reference
                        ** an object */
```

## Null Reference Variables

When you declare a reference variable without specifying default null, the variable points to an object whose 
attributes are automatically initialized with the default values given in the definition of the object. However, you 
can set a reference variable to null. A reference variable that is set to null does not point to any object. Whenever 
all reference variables for an object have been redirected or set to null, OpenROAD frees the associated object, for 
example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
```

The consequences of resetting the variables a and b would be:

```
a = b;     /*  The original object for a is freed. Now
            ** both a and b point to the same object. */
a = null;  /*  The object created for b still has 1
            ** reference (b). */
b = null:  /*  The object created for b is freed. */
```

As an alternative, you can specify default null on the declaration and a default object is not created.

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

```
if a is null then
    /* processing statements */
endif;
```

For more information about null reference variables, see Nulls in Expressions.

## How You Can Create Objects for Reference Variables

You may need to create an object for a reference variable. For example, dynamic programs can create fields or forms 
at runtime by using the Create method, defined for the Class class. The Create method returns an object of a 
specified class.

In the following example, the reference variable a is declared with a default value of null:

```
a = Addr default null;
```

And a new object is created for it:

```
a = Addr.Create();    /* Creates an Addr object */
a.Street = 'main street';
a.City = 'dallas';
```

For more information about the Create method, see the Class class Create Method. Examples of using the Create method 
are provided in "Creating a Frame at Runtime" in the Programming Guide.

output:

```
a = New Address;  /* Creates a new 'Address' object and sets 'a' to point to it. */
b = Null;          /* Sets 'b' to point to no object. */
```

# Reference Variables

A reference variable is a variable that points to an object of a given class, letting you access the value of an 
object. An object is a compound data structure that holds values that you can manipulate. A reference variable does 
not store its own values. Instead, when you reference the reference variable, OpenROAD uses the values in the 
corresponding object. The object is made up of attributes, which can be simple variables, reference variables, or 
array variables.

The class of an object defines its attributes. OpenROAD includes both system classes and user-defined classes.

In your 4GL code, when you reference a reference variable, you can work with the entire object as a single unit. For 
example, you can retrieve a row from a database table and assign all values from the row to a single object and then 
pass the object to a called procedure. You can also work with the individual attributes in the object.

## How You Can Declare Reference Variables

To declare a reference variable, use the following syntax:

```
name = class [ [with] default null]
```

The value of class can be any named user class or system class (for a complete list of system classes, see the 
Language Reference Guide online help). The following example declares a reference variable of the StringObject class:

```
strobj = StringObject;
```

All reference variables are nullable.

When you create a field on a form, you specify the variable's name and data type on the field's property inspector in 
the OpenROAD Workbench. Unless you specify otherwise, OpenROAD automatically declares the variable that you use to 
access the data in that field. If the field is a named composite field, such as a stackfield or subform, the variable 
is a reference variable and you may or may not define its data type (class).

If you do define the data type for the reference variable, the data type must be a system or user class name. You can 
choose to exclude fields for some of the attributes (this provides a way to keep additional undisplayed control 
information).

If you do not name the class when you create a composite field, OpenROAD creates an unnamed class that you can 
reference only within the frame that contains the composite field.

## How You Can Use Reference Variables

In OpenROAD, you can work with an object as a whole or with the attributes of the object. To manipulate the object as 
a single unit, use the name of the object's reference variable in your 4GL code.

For example, you can create a subform and specify its variable's class as a named user class. In your program you 
could then pass the values in the subform fields to a procedure simply by naming the variable as a procedure 
parameter.

In the following statement, customer is the name of the variable associated with a subform:

```
callproc update_cust (new = customer)
```

To access an individual attribute that belongs to an object, use the dot notation:

```
referencevariable_name.attribute_name
```

For example, assume that the subform previously described contained a field called Address. To reference that field, 
you would use:

```
customer.Address
```

In the following example, City and Street are attributes of class addr, and address is a declared reference variable:

```
address.City = 'Dallas';
x = address.Street;
callframe delete_old (address = address.City);
```

OpenROAD checks references to attributes by name and produces compiler errors if the variable's class does not 
contain those attributes. For example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
tmp_char = varchar(30) not null;
```

Some valid references would be:

```
a.Street = tmp_char;
tmp_char = a.city;
```

Some invalid references would be:

```
a.Province = tmp_char;  /*  ERROR at compile time
                        ** because attribute 'province'
                        ** is not defined for class 'addr' */
a = null;
a.Street = tmp_char;    /*  ERROR at runtime because 'a' is
                        ** null, and does not reference
                        ** an object */
```

## Null Reference Variables

When you declare a reference variable without specifying default null, the variable points to an object whose 
attributes are automatically initialized with the default values given in the definition of the object. However, you 
can set a reference variable to null. A reference variable that is set to null does not point to any object. Whenever 
all reference variables for an object have been redirected or set to null, OpenROAD frees the associated object, for 
example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
```

The consequences of resetting the variables a and b would be:

```
a = b;     /*  The original object for a is freed. Now
            ** both a and b point to the same object. */
a = null;  /*  The object created for b still has 1
            ** reference (b). */
b = null:  /*  The object created for b is freed. */
```

As an alternative, you can specify default null on the declaration and a default object is not created.

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

```
if a is null then
    /* processing statements */
endif;
```

For more information about null reference variables, see Nulls in Expressions.

You may need to create an object for a reference variable. For example, dynamic programs can create fields or forms 
at runtime by using the Create method, defined for the Class class. The Create method returns an object of a 
specified class.

In the following example, the reference variable a is declared with a default value of null:

```
a = Addr default null;
```

And a new object is created for it:

```
a = Addr.Create();    /* Creates an Addr object */
a.Street = 'main street';
a.City = 'dallas';
```

For more information about the Create method, see the Class class Create Method. Examples of using the Create method 
are provided in "Creating a Frame at Runtime" in the Programming Guide.

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second, 
movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

For information about referencing the individual elements in a reference or array variable, see Reference Variables 
and Dynamic Array Variables.

instruction: How do you use simple variables in OpenROAD to assign values to reference variables or arrays?
output:
To use simple variables in OpenROAD to assign values to reference variables or arrays, you can use the variable name
for each individual element. For example, to assign the value of Hitchcock to the Director attribute in a reference
variable 'Film', use the following statement:
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
Similarly, to assign the value of Annie Hall to the Title element of an individual movie element in an array 'Movies',
use the following statement:
movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL';

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second, 
movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

For information about referencing the individual elements in a reference or array variable, see Reference Variables 
and Dynamic Array Variables.

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second, 
movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

For information about referencing the individual elements in a reference or array variable, see Reference Variables 
and Dynamic Array Variables.

corresponding object. The object is made up of attributes, which can be simple variables, reference variables, or

The class of an object defines its attributes. OpenROAD includes both system classes and user-defined classes.

In your 4GL code, when you reference a reference variable, you can work with the entire object as a single unit. For 
example, you can retrieve a row from a database table and assign all values from the row to a single object and then 
pass the object to a called procedure. You can also work with the individual attributes in the object.

## How You Can Declare Reference Variables

To declare a reference variable, use the following syntax:

```
name = class [ [with] default null]
```

The value of class can be any named user class or system class (for a complete list of system classes, see the 
Language Reference Guide online help). The following example declares a reference variable of the StringObject class:

```
strobj = StringObject;
```

All reference variables are nullable.

When you create a field on a form, you specify the variable's name and data type on the field's property inspector in 
the OpenROAD Workbench. Unless you specify otherwise, OpenROAD automatically declares the variable that you use to 
access the data in that field. If the field is a named composite field, such as a stackfield or subform, the variable 
is a reference variable and you may or may not define its data type (class).

If you do define the data type for the reference variable, the data type must be a system or user class name. You can 
choose to exclude fields for some of the attributes (this provides a way to keep additional undisplayed control 
information).

If you do not name the class when you create a composite field, OpenROAD creates an unnamed class that you can 
reference only within the frame that contains the composite field.

## How You Can Use Reference Variables

In OpenROAD, you can work with an object as a whole or with the attributes of the object. To manipulate the object as 
a single unit, use the name of the object's reference variable in your 4GL code.

For example, you can create a subform and specify its variable's class as a named user class. In your program you 
could then pass the values in the subform fields to a procedure simply by naming the variable as a procedure 
parameter.

In the following statement, customer is the name of the variable associated with a subform:

```
callproc update_cust (new = customer)
```

To access an individual attribute that belongs to an object, use the dot notation:

```
referencevariable_name.attribute_name
```

For example, assume that the subform previously described contained a field called Address. To reference that field, 
you would use:

```
customer.Address
```

In the following example, City and Street are attributes of class addr, and address is a declared reference variable:

```
address.City = 'Dallas';
x = address.Street;
callframe delete_old (address = address.City);
```

OpenROAD checks references to attributes by name and produces compiler errors if the variable's class does not 
contain those attributes. For example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
tmp_char = varchar(30) not null;
```

Some valid references would be:

```
a.Street = tmp_char;
tmp_char = a.city;
```

Some invalid references would be:

```
a.Province = tmp_char;  /*  ERROR at compile time
                        ** because attribute 'province'
                        ** is not defined for class 'addr' */
a = null;
a.Street = tmp_char;    /*  ERROR at runtime because 'a' is
                        ** null, and does not reference
                        ** an object */
```

## Null Reference Variables

When you declare a reference variable without specifying default null, the variable points to an object whose 
attributes are automatically initialized with the default values given in the definition of the object. However, you 
can set a reference variable to null. A reference variable that is set to null does not point to any object. Whenever 
all reference variables for an object have been redirected or set to null, OpenROAD frees the associated object, for 
example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
```

The consequences of resetting the variables a and b would be:

```
a = b;     /*  The original object for a is freed. Now
            ** both a and b point to the same object. */
a = null;  /*  The object created for b still has 1
            ** reference (b). */
b = null:  /*  The object created for b is freed. */
```

As an alternative, you can specify default null on the declaration and a default object is not created.

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

```
if a is null then
    /* processing statements */
endif;
```

For more information about null reference variables, see Nulls in Expressions.

## How You Can Create Objects for Reference Variables

You may need to create an object for a reference variable. For example, dynamic programs can create fields or forms 
at runtime by using the Create method, defined for the Class class. The Create method returns an object of a 
specified class.

In the following example, the reference variable a is declared with a default value of null:

```
a = Addr default null;
```

And a new object is created for it:

```
a = Addr.Create();    /* Creates an Addr object */
a.Street = 'main street';
a.City = 'dallas';
```

For more information about the Create method, see the Class class Create Method. Examples of using the Create method 
are provided in "Creating a Frame at Runtime" in the Programming Guide.

endif;

instruction: What happens when a reference variable that references an object is set to null?
output:
When a reference variable is set to null, it loses its connection with the corresponding object in memory. Any code that relies on this reference variable will no longer be able to access the object's attributes.

For example:

```
a = Addr;   /*  'a' now points to an 'Addr' object */
b = null;   /*  Now, 'b' is not associated with any object */
```

In this case, the variable b is no longer associated with an object in memory. The statement a = Addr assigns the address of the object pointed to by a to the variable b. However, setting b to null breaks this connection, and a can no longer access the attributes of the object through the reference variable b.

What are the rules for declaring and using simple variables in OpenROAD? What are the differences between simple variables
in OpenROAD and other programming languages?
output:
The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

```
*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*];
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the
not null clause in the declaration.

The with null and not default clauses have no effect in OpenROAD.

In OpenROAD, all simple numeric variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the
*Language Reference Guide* online help.

In OpenROAD, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use other
simple variables. For example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In OpenROAD, unlike some other programming languages, there are no special rules for declaring and using simple
variables. There is no need to declare the scope of a variable before using it. There is no need to explicitly
declare that a variable is local to a procedure or module. There is no need to use a specific data type keyword when
assigning a value to a variable.

In OpenROAD, all simple variables have the same name space. There are no namespaces associated with modules or procedures.
Therefore, there can be no conflicts between identifiers that are assigned to different simple variables.

* The need for explicit declaration of scope before using the variable in some other programming languages
* The need for explicit declaration of data type when assigning a value to the variable in some other programming languages
* The presence of special rules and limitations that apply only to certain types of variables, such as global
variables or procedure local variables, in some other programming languages

development of various programming languages.

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second, 
movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

For information about referencing the individual elements in a reference or array variable, see Reference Variables 
and Dynamic Array Variables.

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second, 
movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

For information about referencing the individual elements in a reference or array variable, see Reference Variables 
and Dynamic Array Variables.

# Reference Variables

A reference variable is a variable that points to an object of a given class, letting you access the value of an 
object. An object is a compound data structure that holds values that you can manipulate. A reference variable does 
not store its own values. Instead, when you reference the reference variable, OpenROAD uses the values in the 
corresponding object. The object is made up of attributes, which can be simple variables, reference variables, or 
array variables.

The class of an object defines its attributes. OpenROAD includes both system classes and user-defined classes.

In your 4GL code, when you reference a reference variable, you can work with the entire object as a single unit. For 
example, you can retrieve a row from a database table and assign all values from the row to a single object and then 
pass the object to a called procedure. You can also work with the individual attributes in the object.

## How You Can Declare Reference Variables

To declare a reference variable, use the following syntax:

```
name = class [ [with] default null]
```

The value of class can be any named user class or system class (for a complete list of system classes, see the 
Language Reference Guide online help). The following example declares a reference variable of the StringObject class:

```
strobj = StringObject;
```

All reference variables are nullable.

When you create a field on a form, you specify the variable's name and data type on the field's property inspector in 
the OpenROAD Workbench. Unless you specify otherwise, OpenROAD automatically declares the variable that you use to 
access the data in that field. If the field is a named composite field, such as a stackfield or subform, the variable 
is a reference variable and you may or may not define its data type (class).

If you do define the data type for the reference variable, the data type must be a system or user class name. You can 
choose to exclude fields for some of the attributes (this provides a way to keep additional undisplayed control 
information).

If you do not name the class when you create a composite field, OpenROAD creates an unnamed class that you can 
reference only within the frame that contains the composite field.

## How You Can Use Reference Variables

In OpenROAD, you can work with an object as a whole or with the attributes of the object. To manipulate the object as 
a single unit, use the name of the object's reference variable in your 4GL code.

For example, you can create a subform and specify its variable's class as a named user class. In your program you 
could then pass the values in the subform fields to a procedure simply by naming the variable as a procedure 
parameter.

In the following statement, customer is the name of the variable associated with a subform:

```
callproc update_cust (new = customer)
```

To access an individual attribute that belongs to an object, use the dot notation:

```
referencevariable_name.attribute_name
```

For example, assume that the subform previously described contained a field called Address. To reference that field, 
you would use:

```
customer.Address
```

In the following example, City and Street are attributes of class addr, and address is a declared reference variable:

```
address.City = 'Dallas';
x = address.Street;
callframe delete_old (address = address.City);
```

OpenROAD checks references to attributes by name and produces compiler errors if the variable's class does not 
contain those attributes. For example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
tmp_char = varchar(30) not null;
```

Some valid references would be:

```
a.Street = tmp_char;
tmp_char = a.city;
```

Some invalid references would be:

```
a.Province = tmp_char;  /*  ERROR at compile time
                        ** because attribute 'province'
                        ** is not defined for class 'addr' */
a = null;
a.Street = tmp_char;    /*  ERROR at runtime because 'a' is
                        ** null, and does not reference
                        ** an object */
```

## Null Reference Variables

When you declare a reference variable without specifying default null, the variable points to an object whose 
attributes are automatically initialized with the default values given in the definition of the object. However, you 
can set a reference variable to null. A reference variable that is set to null does not point to any object. Whenever 
all reference variables for an object have been redirected or set to null, OpenROAD frees the associated object, for 
example, given the following declarations:

```
a = Addr;
b = Addr;
```

The consequences of resetting the variables a and b would be:

```
a = b;     /*  The original object for a is freed. Now
            ** both a and b point to the same object. */
a = null;  /*  The object created for b still has 1
            ** reference (b). */
b = null:  /*  The object created for b is freed. */
```

As an alternative, you can specify default null on the declaration and a default object is not created.

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

You can check for a null reference variable with the is null operator, for example:

```
if a is null then
    /* processing statements */
endif;
```

For more information about null reference variables, see Nulls in Expressions.

## How You Can Create Objects for Reference Variables

You may need to create an object for a reference variable. For example, dynamic programs can create fields or forms 
at runtime by using the Create method, defined for the Class class. The Create method returns an object of a 
specified class.

In the following example, the reference variable a is declared with a default value of null:

```
a = Addr default null;
```

And a new object is created for it:

```
a = Addr.Create();    /* Creates an Addr object */
a.Street = 'main street';
a.City = 'dallas';
```

For more information about the Create method, see the Class class Create Method. Examples of using the Create method 
are provided in "Creating a Frame at Runtime" in the Programming Guide.

# Simple Variables

A simple variable is a single data item. It contains only one value. A simple variable can be any of the basic data 
types, such as integer or varchar, with the exception of table_key and object_key as described in Data Types.

## How You Can Declare Simple Variables

The syntax for declaring a simple variable is:

*name* = *datatype* [with null|not null] [not default|with default|[with] default *defaultvalue*]

The following example shows a local variable declaration for an integer variable:

```
i = integer;
```

By default, all simple variables are nullable. If you do not want the variable to be nullable, you must include the 
not null clause in the declaration, for example:

```
i = integer not null;
```

By default, all numeric simple variables are assigned a default value of zero, and all character simple variables are 
assigned a default value of the empty string (''). If you want to specify a different default value, you must include 
the default clause. The default value must be null, a literal, or one of the system constants defined in the 
*Language Reference Guide* online help, for example:

```
i = integer not null default false;
```

The with null, not default, and with default (without a value) clauses are provided for syntactic compatibility with 
SQL, but they have no effect in OpenROAD.

## How You Can Use Simple Variables

To make use of a simple variable, use the variable name. For example, to assign the value of Smith to the person 
variable, use the following statement:

```
person = 'Smith';
```

Individual elements in a reference variable or an array can be simple variables, as shown in the illustration in 
Variables. In this illustration, Film is a reference variable with three attributes. Each of these attributes is a 
simple variable. Similarly, Movies is an array and each individual element in the array is a simple variable.

In a 4GL script, you can use simple variables as reference or array variable elements in any context that you can use 
other simple variables, for example:

```
film.Director = 'Hitchcock';
if movies[].Title = 'ANNIE HALL' then ...
```

In the first example, film.Director is a simple variable that is an element of a reference variable. In the second, 
movies[].Title is a simple variable that is an element of an array.

For information about referencing the individual elements in a reference or array variable, see Reference Variables 
and Dynamic Array Variables.
